description: Mission dialogue export for ElevenLabs voice generation

missions.title: The Audit Trail
missions.voiceDirection: Gruff, working-class, direct. No-nonsense foreman who has seen it all.

lines.text: [gruffly] Twenty-six years I've worked these pipes. My grandfather helped build them. Dad ran them before me.
[bitterly] Twelve years ago, my brother Marcus died right here. Pressure seal failure. Could have been prevented if the company hadn't cut corners.
[angrily] Spent three years fighting for accountability. Won a settlement. Nobody went to jail. Company paid a fine worth one day's profits.
[suspiciously] Now I see the same patterns at Ceres Power Plant. Ivo Renn is manipulating fuel prices. I can't prove it. Yet.
[conspiratorially] I need you to dock at Ceres. Install this monitoring device. Thirty seconds, undetected. Then get out.
[determinedly] If Renn is doing what I think he's doing, this device will prove it. Workers across the system are getting squeezed by his 'market fluctuations.'
[gratefully] Good. My grandfather believed in free markets. Said they regulate themselves. [darkly] Time to prove whether that's still true.
[tensely] Installing now. Keep your head down. Renn's people are everywhere. Don't give them a reason to look closer.
[relieved] Device is active. Already picking up data. [studies readout] Holy... look at these transaction patterns.
[angrily] Renn is buying fuel at market rates, then restricting supply to jack up prices. Forty percent increase in six months. People are going under.
[determinedly] Now we have proof. Question is: what do we do with it? This could change everything... or get us both killed.

missions.title: Fuel the Fire
missions.voiceDirection: Gruff, working-class, direct. No-nonsense foreman who has seen it all.

lines.text: [gruffly] You did good work at Ceres. Device pulled clean data. Clean enough to make a man like Renn sweat.
[angrily] Forty percent fuel spike in six months. Not 'market forces.' Not 'bad timing.' A plan. People rationing power because one suit wants a prettier graph.
[determinedly] I can take this evidence to the stations that matter. Greenfields, Drydock, Freeport. Harlan will back us—he's been waiting fifteen years for someone to punch a hole in corporate lies.
[pauses] But… he already knows. Your ship left a wake. Renn just pinged my private comm. Offered you money to bury it.
[bitterly] That's the part that makes me sick. He thinks everything has a price tag. Like my brother's death did.
[directly] This is the fork. Expose him and you make enemies with deep pockets. Take his deal and you cash in while the system burns. Your call, pilot.
[grimly] Alright. No walking it back now. Whatever you picked… we live with it.
[quietly] Choice made. Now the hard part starts.

missions.title: The Blockade - Raid Refinery Shipments
missions.voiceDirection: Dry, calculating, subtle menace. Every word is deliberate.

lines.text: [calculatingly] Rex Calder is trying to flood the lanes with cheap fuel. He calls it freedom. I call it sabotage with better branding.
[coldly] Ceres keeps eight stations powered. Hospitals. Air recyclers. Hydroponics. Systems that don't tolerate ideology.
[quietly] I watched a grid fail once. People froze while the lights died. You don't forget that lesson. If prices crash and we sell at a loss, the grid doesn't get poetic. It fails.
[coldly] Three convoys. Remove them. Not theft—termination of a destabilizing variable.
[menacingly] You're worried how this looks. Good. An untroubled conscience is usually an empty one.
[directly] Ten minutes. Three targets. Do it cleanly, and you'll be compensated for keeping the lights on.
[satisfied] Excellent. Efficiency, then. No theatrics.
[flatly] First convoy removed. Note how the market immediately adjusts. Disorder hates a vacuum—so does opportunity.
[urgent] Time is the only resource you can't buy back. Finish the work.
[pleased] Convoys neutralized. Price volatility contained. Grid stability preserved.
[dry] Rex will call you a villain. He will not mention the hospitals that stay lit because of you.
[measured] Now we consolidate. Panic creates inventory. Inventory creates power. Return when you're ready to be useful again.

missions.title: The Blockade - Defend Refinery Convoys
missions.voiceDirection: Gruff, working-class, direct. No-nonsense foreman who has seen it all.

lines.text: [grimly] He didn't deny it. Didn't apologize. He retaliated.
[urgent] Three fuel convoys are lifting off right now—Greenfields, Freeport, Drydock. Civilian haulers. Families. Not combat pilots.
[angrily] Renn hired professionals. Not the usual opportunists. They don't want the fuel—they want the message: 'Stay quiet or starve.'
[tensely] Expect four waves. Hit-and-run interceptors. They'll try to isolate each convoy and carve it up fast.
[hard] I'm flying with them. Somebody has to. I've spent my life watching people 'ensure stability' by breaking workers.
[directly] Keep those ships alive. Keep that fuel moving. If we fold here, the monopoly comes back wearing a nicer suit.
[grateful] Good. Weapons hot, eyes open. They won't stop until somebody bleeds.
[relieved] Freeport convoy just cleared the kill zone. One down. Keep moving—don't let them reset on the next target.
[alarmed] Contacts! First wave inbound—tight formation, corporate-grade comms. This isn't a shakedown, it's a hit!
[exhausted] They're gone. Convoys are intact. Fuel delivered. That's what 'free market' looks like—people doing the work without a gun to their head.
[quietly] Renn expected us to flinch. To run back to him begging for stability. Not today.
[determinedly] One last push. We break his leverage for good. I've got a plan—meet me in the conference room.
[hollow] A convoy didn't make it. Families won't get refunds. [pauses] This is what he buys with his money.

missions.title: Consolidate Control - Fuel Market Domination
missions.voiceDirection: Dry, calculating, subtle menace. Every word is deliberate.

lines.text: [calmly] Instability has a predictable shape. First: outrage. Then: panic. Finally: consolidation by whoever planned ahead.
[measured] Right now, every station is buying fuel like tomorrow is a myth. We will acquire that inventory before they do.
[dry] Five stations. Twelve minutes. Buy every unit of refined fuel you can find. Pay whatever they demand. I will reimburse double.
[quietly] You think this is hoarding. I think it's reserve capacity. The difference is whether you prefer certainty or sermons.
[cool] When the next supply shock hits—and it will—Ceres will have fuel. Hospitals will have power. And the system will thank us quietly.
[directly] Move. The market is a race, and sentiment is dead weight.
[pleased] Good. I appreciate contractors who understand timelines.
[urgent] Final minute. Deliver. Or the opportunity becomes someone else's.
[approvingly] Two stations cleared. Keep momentum. The window closes faster than people think.
[satisfied] Inventory secured. Prices stabilized under a single, coherent policy. This is what competence looks like.
[dry] Rex will keep telling stories about freedom. Meanwhile, the grid will keep running. Stories don't keep oxygen flowing.
[quietly] You have proven reliable. In this system, reliability is rarer than fuel.

missions.title: New Sources - Independent Refinery
missions.voiceDirection: Gruff, working-class, direct. No-nonsense foreman who has seen it all.

lines.text: [lighter] You felt that? The market breathed again. Not perfect—just… not strangled.
[excitedly] Freeport's got engineers ready to spin up a micro-refinery. Small. Distributed. Enough to make sure Ceres can never corner supply again.
[practical] We need feedstock. Catalyst-grade rare minerals from the outer belt. Forty units. That's the ticket price for independence.
[warmly] Kalla's calling it 'insurance.' I call it dignity. When fuel stops being a weapon, people can plan their lives again.
[quietly] My granddad built these towers thinking fair trade was inevitable. Like gravity. Turns out you have to fight for it, every day.
[directly] Bring those minerals to Freeport. Once that micro-refinery goes online, no one man gets to decide who freezes and who flies.
[grateful] Good. Fly smart. If Renn's watching, let him watch you build something he can't buy.
[encouraging] Halfway there. Keep the cargo sealed tight—those minerals are worth more than your hull plating right now.
[overcome] Forty units delivered. Freeport's crew is already unloading. You just bought this system a future.
[warmly] Prices will still swing. Traders will still hustle. But nobody gets to manufacture famine and call it 'optimization.'
[quietly] Marcus would've liked this. Something real. Something that lasts. Thanks, pilot. Truly.

missions.title: Patent Wars - Aurum Path
missions.voiceDirection: Clinical, precise, emotionally detached. Scientist first, human second.

lines.text: [clinically] I spent eight years at Titan Research. My partner was brilliant—intuitive, passionate, everything I'm not.
[pauses] Then Lab 7 happened. A decimal point. One small human error. Three people died. Including my mentor.
[flatly] My partner fled technology entirely. I... went the other direction. If humans make errors, design systems where errors can't happen.
[businesslike] Chief Harlan at Drydock represents everything I oppose. Artisanal fabrication. 'Craftsmanship.' Three hundred workers doing what machines could do better.
[precisely] He has schematics I need. Alloy formulas. Intellectual property that would accelerate our automation by months.
[directly] Dock at Drydock. Access their systems. Download the data. Return here. [pauses] Can you operate with precision?
[approvingly] Efficiency begets efficiency. Your reliability metrics will be updated accordingly. Proceed.
[calmly] Data transfer in progress. Maintain your position. Interruptions create... complications.
[pleased] Data received. Analyzing now. [pauses] These formulas will save approximately four hundred labor-hours per cycle.
[quietly] Chief Harlan will consider this theft. He doesn't understand that information wants to be optimized, not hoarded.
[businesslike] Your partnership value has increased significantly. Expect priority allocation on future transactions.

missions.title: Patent Wars - Drydock Path
missions.voiceDirection: Blue-collar, loyal, weathered. Union man through and through.

lines.text: [gruffly] My father died on this floor. Shot by company security during the Shipyard Strikes. I was twenty-two.
[heavily] Watched him fall. Watched him bleed. [pauses] The strike succeeded. Workers got their demands. Dad became a martyr.
[steeling himself] That's why I do what I do. Three hundred workers here. Three hundred families. They're not 'labor costs.' They're people.
[frustrated] Dr. Kade at Aurum Fab thinks automation is progress. She looks at my floor and sees inefficiency. I look at it and see lives.
[conspiratorially] We've developed fake schematics. Wrong enough to send her research in circles for months. I need you to plant them.
[directly] Dock at Aurum Fab. Upload the data chip. Let Kade waste her precious efficiency chasing ghosts. Can you do this for us?
[warmly] Union thanks you. Workers thank you. [chuckles] And I personally owe you a drink when this is done.
[laughs] Kade's probably running those schematics through her precious algorithms right now. [grins] Let her optimize nonsense.
[seriously] This buys us time. Time to prove that quality beats efficiency. Time to show Ceres who they should trust.
[warmly] You're one of us now. The crew's already talking about you. That's rare. That means something.

missions.title: Raw Materials Rush - Aurum Path
missions.voiceDirection: Clinical, precise, emotionally detached. Scientist first, human second.

lines.text: [clinically] You may think this is about pride. It isn't. It's about throughput. Inputs. Bottlenecks. Outcomes.
[precisely] Drydock requires copper ore and silicon to keep its fabrication floor alive. Remove the inputs, and the system stalls.
[flatly] Economic warfare has fewer funerals. Mostly. It still ruins lives—just quietly, on spreadsheets.
[businesslike] Eight minutes. Three stations. Buy every unit of copper ore and silicon you can find. Pay the premium. I will reimburse it.
[quietly] Harlan will call this cruelty. He called Lab 7 an accident. Both were preventable. Both were human.
[directly] Deliver the materials to Aurum. Keep the timeline. Time wasted is work wasted.
[approvingly] Good. Acquire the inputs. Deny the inefficiency its oxygen.
[pleased] Materials received. Supply secured. Drydock's procurement team will discover the shortage shortly.
[measured] They will blame markets. They should blame planning. The world rewards those who anticipate.
[businesslike] Stage three begins when they try to compensate. We will prevent that compensation.
[coldly] Then we lose initiative. I do not like losing initiative. Try again, or step aside.

missions.title: Raw Materials Rush - Drydock Path
missions.voiceDirection: Blue-collar, loyal, weathered. Union man through and through.

lines.text: [gruffly] Kade's not trying to beat us. She's trying to starve us. Same trick the companies used during the strikes.
[angrily] You cut the copper and silicon, you don't just slow machines. You send people home. You tell families to eat their pride.
[heavily] I promised this crew I'd protect them. Not with speeches—with supply lines that actually show up.
[determinedly] Eight minutes. Three stations. Buy every unit of copper ore and silicon you can find. Pay what it takes.
[quietly] I hate playing these games. But Kade wrote the rules with a clean pen and dirty hands. We adapt or we die.
[directly] Bring it here. Keep my floor lit. Keep my people working.
[warmly] Good. Move fast. The market's a knife fight, and we're not the ones who started swinging.
[relieved] That's it. That's the feedstock. You just bought this yard a week of breathing room.
[grimly] Kade will retaliate. She doesn't lose gracefully. She loses like a machine—cold, efficient, and vindictive.
[determinedly] Next, we hit her supply chain before she hits ours. I wish there was another way. There isn't.
[hollow] Then the floor goes quiet. And quiet costs more than credits. Damn it.

missions.title: Sabotage the Supply Line
missions.voiceDirection: Clinical, precise, emotionally detached. Scientist first, human second.

lines.text: [businesslike] Supply lines are the soft underbelly of any production system. Cut them, and the machinery follows.
[precisely] Five traders are currently hauling electronics and alloys to our competitor. High-value cargo. Low-value ethics.
[flatly] You will destroy them before they dock. Ten minutes. Five targets. No delays.
[quietly] I am aware this is brutal. So is unemployment. So is a system that rewards whoever pulls the first lever.
[clinically] Consider this a demonstration. Not of violence—of leverage.
[directly] Execute. Then return.
[approvingly] Understood. Keep it efficient.
[satisfied] Five targets removed. The supply chain disruption is complete.
[measured] Markets will adjust. They always do. The question is who benefits from the adjustment.
[businesslike] Good work. The next phase will be... decisive.
[coldly] Then the shipments landed and the window closed. Try again, or accept irrelevance.

missions.title: Sabotage the Supply Line - Aurum Path
missions.voiceDirection: Clinical, precise, emotionally detached. Scientist first, human second.

lines.text: [businesslike] Drydock has found emergency suppliers. Independent haulers. Five shipments that keep their floor alive.
[precisely] Electronics and alloys. Each shipment is a temporary patch over a structurally inefficient system.
[flatly] If those shipments arrive, our advantage collapses. If they don't, the market resolves itself.
[quietly] You are not hunting villains. You are interrupting logistics. I understand the distinction doesn't help.
[clinically] Ten minutes. Five targets. Remove the shipments before they dock. Do it cleanly. Do it quickly.
[directly] Efficiency requires decisive action. Sentiment delays. Delay costs lives in subtler ways.
[approvingly] Proceed. Maintain focus. The future does not wait for anyone's conscience to catch up.
[satisfied] Targets eliminated. Drydock's emergency supply plan has failed.
[measured] Harlan will call this monstrous. He never asks what happens when inefficient systems collapse naturally.
[quietly] Stage four is a race. No sabotage. No theatrics. Just delivery. Win it.
[coldly] Then they recovered. You gave them time. Time is the only advantage you cannot buy back.

missions.title: Sabotage the Supply Line - Drydock Path
missions.voiceDirection: Blue-collar, loyal, weathered. Union man through and through.

lines.text: [heavily] I never wanted to point you at civilian haulers. But Kade's bringing in five shipments that lock us out for months.
[grimly] Electronics and alloys. The kind of contracts that keep a small outfit alive. And she's using them like ammunition.
[angrily] You let those shipments dock and my floor goes dark. People get laid off. People lose homes. That's her math.
[quietly] I know what I'm asking. I can hear my father's voice telling me not to become what killed him.
[determinedly] Ten minutes. Five targets. Stop those shipments before they dock. Save this yard.
[directly] Do it fast. Do it merciful, if that's a thing in space. Then come back. We finish this with a fair race.
[grimly] Alright. No more pretending this is clean. Bring them down and get home.
[exhausted] It's done. Those shipments won't dock. The crew's still working. For now.
[quietly] I'm going to carry this. Not you. I asked. You answered. That's on me.
[resolutely] Stage four is simple: deliver the contract cargo to Ceres first. No tricks. Just proof that workers can win.
[hollow] Then we lost the window. Kade's shipments landed. She's going to squeeze us until something breaks.

missions.title: The Exclusive Contract - Aurum Path
missions.voiceDirection: Clinical, precise, emotionally detached. Scientist first, human second.

lines.text: [measured] Ceres Power Plant has issued an exclusive supplier contract. Five years. Advanced fabrication only. Winner takes the pipeline.
[precisely] Fifty units of mixed fabricated goods. Tight tolerances. No substitutions. No partial deliveries. Full manifest or nothing.
[quietly] If we win, we validate the model: standardized processes, predictable outputs, fewer Lab 7 moments.
[flatly] Drydock will compete. Hand-checked parts. Pride. Ritual. None of it matters if they arrive second.
[businesslike] Take the cargo. Fly directly to Ceres. Do not detour for profit. This is profit.
[directly] Deliver first. End the war with a receipt.
[approvingly] Good. The contract is a finish line. Cross it.
[pleased] Dock confirmed. Manifest accepted. Ceres has signed. Aurum Fab is now their exclusive supplier.
[softly] This is what I wanted at Titan: systems that don't depend on perfect humans. Maybe now we get closer.
[businesslike] Your reliability metrics are exceptional. Aurum will allocate accordingly. Congratulations, pilot.
[coldly] Second place is not a category in procurement. We lost the contract. The system will remember that failure.

missions.title: The Exclusive Contract - Drydock Path
missions.voiceDirection: Blue-collar, loyal, weathered. Union man through and through.

lines.text: [proudly] Ceres put out an exclusive contract. Five years. Fifty units. The kind of deal that keeps a station alive.
[warmly] The crew pulled a double shift. Every part checked by hand. Not because it's efficient—because it's ours.
[heavily] Kade will call this sentiment. Like caring is a flaw. I call it the only reason work means anything.
[determinedly] This is the end. No more sabotage. No more supply games. Just a race to Ceres with a full manifest.
[quietly] Deliver first, and you prove a yard full of workers can beat a lab full of machines.
[directly] Take the cargo. Fly like everyone here is riding in your hold. Because they are.
[warmly] Alright. Bring it home. And when you dock, let them see the union mark on every crate.
[overcome] You did it. Ceres accepted the manifest. Contract signed. Five years of work secured.
[laughs] The floor erupted when we got the confirmation. People crying. People hugging. In a shipyard. Imagine that.
[seriously] My father died believing workers could win. Today, we proved it. Thank you, pilot. Truly.
[hollow] We were second. Second doesn't pay wages. Second doesn't keep the lights on. Damn it.

missions.title: Breaking the Chain
missions.voiceDirection: Warm, earthy, quietly fierce. Farmer who fights with patience and resolve.

lines.text: [warmly] I remember my first years in this system. Working alongside Elin Kade at Titan Research, believing technology would solve everything.
[pauses] Then Lab 7 happened. Friends died because a decimal point was wrong. I learned that day—some problems can't be automated away.
[determined] That's why I'm here, growing real food with real hands. Simple. Honest. But Sol City wants to complicate everything.
[frustrated] Mira Vale—she was an inspector here once. Young, ambitious, convinced regulations protect people. Maybe they do, sometimes.
[conspiratorially] But right now, her regulations are strangling us. I need luxury goods for a... private arrangement. Off the books.
[urgently] Ten units. Don't fly near Sol City—their inspectors will confiscate anything that doesn't have proper stamps. Can you do this?
[grateful] Thank you. The cooperative won't forget this. Now fly careful—and fly smart.
[encouraging] You're doing great. Just a little further. The workers are already preparing the distribution lists.
[alarmed] Warning! Sol City patrol detected. Change course immediately or they'll scan your cargo!
[joyfully] You made it! [laughs] Look at these goods—Sol City thought they could starve us into compliance.
[warmly] My grandmother grew vegetables on a generation ship. She always said: 'Feed people, and you give them hope.'
[seriously] This is just the beginning. Next time... we're going to need you for something bigger. Something that can't be undone.
[disappointed] Sol City got the cargo. [sighs] I expected too much, too soon. We'll find another way.

missions.title: The Census
missions.voiceDirection: Warm, earthy, quietly fierce. Farmer who fights with patience and resolve.

lines.text: [intensely] Sol City has been conducting 'agricultural inspections.' What they're really doing is building a case against us.
[bitterly] Mira Vale and I worked together once, briefly. I thought we understood each other. But she filed a regulatory report that nearly destroyed us.
[pauses] She sees rules. I see families. We stopped being friends that day.
[urgently] There are data chips in Sol City that contain the real inspection logs. The ones showing their inspectors planted evidence.
[quietly] If you get those chips to me, we expose the corruption. If you take them to Mira instead... [pauses] well, you'd be helping her finish what she started.
[earnestly] This is the moment, pilot. Which future do you want to build?
[hopefully] Whatever you decide... remember that farmers fed this system for generations. We deserve respect, not regulation.
[overwhelmed] These logs... I knew they were lying, but seeing the proof... [voice breaks] My husband Marcus always believed we'd be vindicated.
[determined] Sol City is going to raise prices on us. Make things harder. But they can't bury the truth anymore.
[warmly] You chose our side. That means something. Greenfields will remember.

missions.title: Supply Cut
missions.voiceDirection: Warm, earthy, quietly fierce. Farmer who fights with patience and resolve.

lines.text: [heavily] Harvest season. Should be a celebration. Instead, I'm asking you to destroy ships.
[bitterly] Sol City is intercepting our grain convoys. 'Quality inspections,' they call it. Legalized theft is what it is.
[pauses] I knew the pilots on those convoys once. Shared meals. Shared dreams. [voice hardens] Then they sold out to Sol City security contracts.
[intensely] Three convoys are heading to Sol City right now. If they arrive, Mira Vale uses that grain to prove she controls our food supply.
[quietly] Destroy them. Let Sol City feel what scarcity means. [pauses] Maybe then they'll negotiate in good faith.
[steeling herself] This is economic warfare. The kind that echoes through ledgers and stomachs. Are you ready to cross this line?
[grimly] Then go. And may whatever gods you believe in forgive us both.
[quietly] First convoy down. [pauses] I hope they had escape pods. I hope... [trails off]
[hardening] Sol City will call this terrorism. We call it survival. History decides who was right.
[exhausted] It's done. Grain prices in Sol City will spike within the hour. Mira Vale will be scrambling.
[quietly] Some nights I still dream about Lab 7. The screaming. The chemical smell. [pauses] Now I'll dream about grain convoys too.
[resolutely] But freedom isn't free. My grandmother knew that. Crossed half the galaxy in a tin can to find somewhere to grow things in peace.
[warmly] One more step. The final delivery. After that... Greenfields stands alone. Independent. The way it should be.

missions.title: New Markets
missions.voiceDirection: Warm, earthy, quietly fierce. Farmer who fights with patience and resolve.

lines.text: [emotionally] Come in. Sit. [pauses] The kitchen smells like fresh bread. My grandmother's recipe. Same one she baked on the generation ship.
[spreading papers] This contract... it's not just paper. It's everything we've fought for. Kalla Rook at Freeport is buying direct.
[voice breaking] No Sol City inspectors. No middleman tariffs. No compliance fees bleeding us dry quarter after quarter.
[looking outside] See them? Workers loading crates by hand. Singing old work songs from Earth. [smiles] Nobody remembers where the songs come from anymore.
[firmly] Thirty units of food. Grain and meat—the harvest of free farmers going to free traders.
[intensely] This is our shot. One chance to prove we can stand on our own. Get this cargo to Freeport, and we rewrite the rules.
[quietly] My husband Marcus is sick. [pauses] He might not see what we're building. But he'll know it happened. That matters.
[gathering herself] The agricultural revolution begins now. Fly safe. Fly proud. And thank you... for everything.
[overcome] You did it. [laughs through tears] Kalla just confirmed—the cargo arrived. The contract is signed. We're independent!
[laughing] Listen to them! [sound of cheering] The whole station is celebrating. Haven't heard that sound in... I don't know how long.
[warmly] My old colleague Elin would call this 'suboptimal resource allocation.' [chuckles] I call it freedom.
[sincerely] You changed history today. Greenfields will never forget the pilot who believed in us when nobody else did.
[raising a glass] To the harvest. To independence. To everyone who said it couldn't be done. [drinks] Now let's show the system what farmers can build.

missions.title: Diplomatic Pouch
missions.voiceDirection: Street-smart, charming, hint of mischief. The friendly merchant who knows everything.

lines.text: [casually] Used to work intelligence, you know. Eight years gathering secrets for people who didn't deserve them.
[darkly] Found corruption at the top. Filed a report. Got framed for the crime I exposed. Eighteen months in detention.
[lighter] Escaped during a 'transport malfunction.' [winks] Now I run Freeport. Neutral ground. Everyone's welcome if they can pay.
[seriously] Here's the thing: Sol City and Hidden Cove have been at each other's throats for years. Bad for business. Worse for people caught in the middle.
[hopefully] I've drafted a peace proposal. Vex Marrow at Hidden Cove has agreed to read it. But someone needs to deliver it.
[warning] Thirty percent chance of pirate ambush en route. Not everyone in Vex's organization wants peace. [shrugs] Still interested?
[pleased] Brave pilot! Information is the real currency, and right now, this message is worth more than cargo. Fly fast.
[excited] Vex received the proposal! [laughs] I honestly didn't think you'd make it. No offense.
[thoughtfully] Now comes the hard part. Both sides have to choose: keep fighting, or try something new.
[earnestly] Thank you for carrying hope across the void. That sounds dramatic. [chuckles] But it's true.

missions.title: Choose Your Side
missions.voiceDirection: Street-smart, charming, hint of mischief. The friendly merchant who knows everything.

lines.text: [casually] Alright, pilot. You delivered the pouch. Vex read it. Sol City pretended not to. Everyone's pretending. That's how you know it matters.
[seriously] The system's at a fork: Hidden Cove wants freedom, Sol City wants control, and Freeport wants everyone alive enough to keep spending credits.
[darkly] I've seen what happens when nobody chooses. The loudest guns decide for you. Then everyone calls it inevitability.
[measured] Three paths. Join the pirates and raid Sol City convoys. Enforce the law and burn Hidden Cove to the ground. Or buy peace with reparations.
[quietly] None of them are clean. Clean choices are for people who never leave the station.
[directly] Pick your side. And then live with it. This one sticks.
[pleased] Decision made. I'll notify the right people—meaning the people least likely to shoot you on sight. Hopefully.
[thoughtfully] And there it is. A choice. One line in a ledger that turns into ten years of consequences.
[seriously] Whatever you picked—pirates, law, peace—you're now a factor people plan around. That's power, pilot.
[casually] Go on, then. The system's waiting for you to prove you meant it.

missions.title: The Enforcement - Siege Hidden Cove
missions.voiceDirection: Polished, measured, slight condescension. Professional bureaucrat who believes in the system.

lines.text: [professionally] This is not diplomacy. This is enforcement. Hidden Cove has crossed the line between nuisance and threat.
[firmly] They hide behind slogans about freedom while they extort, smuggle, and kill. That is not politics. It's predation.
[measured] Three defense turrets protect their approach lanes. Remove them, and Sol City security can contain the station.
[quietly] Some of them are people you have traded with. That does not absolve them. Familiarity is not innocence.
[hardening] I was a child when Freeport burned. I remember what lawlessness sounds like. I will not let that sound return.
[directly] Three turrets. End the pirate era. Bring the system back under rules that protect everyone.
[formally] Understood. Sol City records your service. Proceed with precision.
[relieved] Turrets destroyed. The approach is clear. Security forces are moving to contain Hidden Cove now.
[softly] This will be called harsh. Perhaps it is. But it is less harsh than letting violence metastasize.
[professionally] Order is restored by people willing to do difficult work. Today, you were one of them.
[coldly] Then the siege fails, and the pirates learn they can resist with impunity. That is unacceptable.

missions.title: The Enforcement - Defend Peace Conference
missions.voiceDirection: Street-smart, charming, hint of mischief. The friendly merchant who knows everything.

lines.text: [exhausted] They're coming. Both of them. Mira Vale and Vex Marrow in the same room. That's either history or a massacre.
[seriously] Extremists on both sides want this to fail. They think peace is betrayal. War is easier to understand than compromise.
[measured] Two waves inbound. First: Sol City hard-liners trying to kill Vex. Second: pirate zealots trying to kill Mira.
[quietly] I used to trade in secrets. Turns out the hardest thing to sell is the idea that your enemy might also be human.
[determined] Defend this hall. Defend the possibility that we end this without burning a station to make a point.
[directly] Hold both waves. If you fail, the war becomes permanent. If you succeed, we all get to keep docking rights.
[grateful] Thank you. I know fighting for peace sounds backwards. Welcome to Freeport.
[overcome] You held the line. Both delegations are alive. They're still arguing—which is perfect.
[laughing] Do you know how rare this is? People choosing paperwork over plasma fire. I'm almost proud of us.
[thoughtfully] Peace isn't a treaty. It's maintenance. But today, we did the first maintenance cycle.
[hollow] Then it collapses. And everyone will call it inevitable. I'll know it wasn't.

missions.title: The Enforcement - Assault Sol City Defenses
missions.voiceDirection: Dangerous charm, playful threat. Every smile has teeth.

lines.text: [seriously] Choice made. No more speeches in back rooms. We hit Sol City's defenses in the open.
[darkening] They built three turrets to remind the system who owns the lanes. Alpha. Beta. Gamma. Symbols with guns.
[triumphantly] Take them down and every captain in the belt learns the same lesson: Sol City bleeds like anyone else.
[quietly] Don't pretend this is clean. It isn't. But neither is a life where your air filters come with a tax stamp.
[hardening] Three turrets. One run. No hesitation. If you hesitate, you die. If we hesitate, we go back to cages with better lighting.
[directly] Weapons hot. Show them what revolution sounds like.
[pleased] Good. Fly like you mean it. We'll be watching the fireworks from here.
[overcome] Turrets down. Do you feel that? That's the system realizing fear isn't a law of physics.
[seriously] Sol City will call you a terrorist. They called me one too—back when I wore their badge.
[triumphantly] Welcome to the Cove, pilot. Freedom is expensive. You just paid the down payment.
[coldly] Then the symbol stands. And symbols are half the war. Get out alive. We'll find another angle.

missions.title: Agricultural Compliance Escort
missions.voiceDirection: Polished, measured, slight condescension. Professional bureaucrat who believes in the system.

lines.text: [tensely] We have evidence of agricultural violations at Greenfields. Unregistered grow operations. Unauthorized seed modifications.
[seriously] This isn't about control. One contaminated crop could sicken thousands. These regulations exist for a reason.
[introducing] Inspector Chavez has been doing this for twenty-three years. She's never needed an armed escort before.
[grimly] Intelligence suggests Sana Whit has hired Hidden Cove pirates to prevent this inspection. Vex Marrow's people. Dangerous.
[pauses] I was stationed at Greenfields once. Young inspector. Sana was kind to me then. [voice hardens] Before she decided the rules didn't apply to farmers.
[firmly] Protect Inspector Chavez. Get her to Greenfields. Let her do her job. That's all I ask.
[formally] Sol City is grateful. Inspector Chavez's shuttle will launch momentarily. Protect her with your life if necessary.
[alarmed] Pirate contacts on scope! Hidden Cove signatures. Protect the inspector!
[relieved] Wave repelled. [pauses] More incoming. They really don't want this inspection to happen.
[relieved] Inspector Chavez has arrived safely. The inspection is proceeding. You've done well.
[quietly] Sana will hate me more now. [pauses] But I didn't create the rules. I just enforce them.
[professionally] One final task remains. Enforcement contracts must be distributed. Greenfields will comply... or face consequences.

missions.title: Contract Enforcement
missions.voiceDirection: Polished, measured, slight condescension. Professional bureaucrat who believes in the system.

lines.text: [professionally] The world runs on contracts, pilot. Not ideals. Not stories. Contracts. They define what happens when people disagree.
[measured] Greenfields violated fourteen regulatory statutes. We have evidence for each infraction. This is not punishment. It's consequence.
[firmly] I need four enforcement contracts delivered—Ceres Power Plant, Aurum Fabricator, Drydock, and Freeport. One seal at each station.
[quietly] Sana will call this oppression. She always does. I call it standards that keep hospitals powered and food uncontaminated.
[hardening] When rules become optional, the first people to suffer aren't the rebels. They're the citizens with no ship and no leverage.
[directly] Deliver the contracts. Let the system see that Sol City enforces what it writes. Civilization depends on follow-through.
[formally] Good. Keep them sealed. Each signature is a line drawn against chaos.
[satisfied] Confirmations received. Four stations. Four seals. The enforcement framework is in place.
[softly] I don't enjoy this. I enjoy stability. And stability is built from decisions people hate in the moment.
[professionally] You chose order. Sol City will remember that choice—and reward it accordingly.
[coldly] Then the message was lost. If we can't enforce contracts, we don't have law—we have suggestions. I won't build a city on suggestions.

missions.title: Organize the Stations
missions.voiceDirection: Blue-collar, loyal, weathered. Union man through and through.

lines.text: [heavily] I'm fifty-three years old. Half my life on this floor. Started when I was twenty, sweeping debris.
[pauses] After my father was killed, I could have become a firebrand. Led riots. Burned things down. Instead, I learned every job in this yard.
[proudly] Now I can do any job here better than anyone. That's why workers follow me. Not because of speeches. Because I'm one of them.
[urgently] We're organizing across stations. Biggest union push in thirty years. But we need help spreading the word.
[determinedly] Five stations. Fifteen minutes. Deliver these pamphlets. Rex at the Refinery is already with us. Sana at Greenfields. Now we need everyone else.
[quietly] Doctor says I've got respiratory damage. Decades of shipyard particulates. [pauses] Haven't told my family yet. But I need to finish what my father started first.
[warmly] Workers built this system. Time we got paid like we matter. Go. And thank you for standing with us.
[encouragingly] First station reached! Workers are reading the pamphlets. The conversation is starting. Keep moving!
[excitedly] Three stations! Rex just commed—the refinery workers are talking strike. We have momentum!
[joyfully] All stations reached! [laughs] Every station in the system is talking about workers' rights. Corporate types are nervous.
[seriously] My father would be proud. He died believing workers could stand together. [voice breaks] Took thirty years, but we're doing it.
[determinedly] Next step: the strike. Or breaking it. Dr. Kade is already offering bounties for strikebreakers. Time to choose your side.

missions.title: Strike or Break
missions.voiceDirection: Blue-collar, loyal, weathered. Union man through and through.

lines.text: [heavily] The pamphlets worked. Every station's talking now. Workers asking questions corporate types hate answering.
[determinedly] Tomorrow at 0600, we strike. Sol City, Aurum, Ceres—operations stop until they negotiate fair terms. No more pretending.
[quietly] And of course, Dr. Kade is already paying for strikebreakers. Calling it 'stability.' Same old word for the same old boot.
[angrily] If you side with her, you keep the machines humming while the people who built them get told to be grateful.
[steadying] If you side with us, you refuse corporate trade for ten minutes. You let the price spikes speak the language they understand.
[directly] This is the fork. Dignity or efficiency. People or graphs. Choose.
[grimly] Alright. No speeches left. Just consequences.
[quietly] Choice logged. The system will react fast. So will the people in charge.
[seriously] Whatever you picked, the next stage is where it gets real. Victory isn't a vote. It's follow-through.
[determinedly] Get ready, pilot. The strike starts in the morning—one way or another.

missions.title: The Negotiations - Corporate Victory
missions.voiceDirection: Clinical, precise, emotionally detached. Scientist first, human second.

lines.text: [flatly] The strike is broken. Operations have resumed. That is the first requirement for a stable system.
[measured] Chief Harlan still demands arbitration. Kalla Rook offers mediation. Fine. We will negotiate from strength, not panic.
[clinically] Negotiation without data is theater. I need operating costs, profit margins, labor expenses—six stations, full picture.
[quietly] Harlan thinks facts will vindicate him. Perhaps. Or perhaps they reveal that his demands collapse the supply chain.
[precisely] Collect the data. Deliver it to Freeport. Then I will sit across from him and discuss terms that preserve output.
[directly] Do not moralize. Just measure. Bring me numbers.
[approvingly] Good. Data is leverage. Acquire it.
[satisfied] Data delivered. Arbitration can proceed with facts instead of rhetoric.
[measured] Perhaps we find compromise. Perhaps we prove unions are inefficient. Either outcome is acceptable if it is true.
[businesslike] You have been useful. The system rewards usefulness.

missions.title: The Negotiations - Union Victory
missions.voiceDirection: Blue-collar, loyal, weathered. Union man through and through.

lines.text: [overcome] The strike held. They tried to wait us out. Then the numbers hit them like a wrench to the teeth.
[proudly] Kalla at Freeport is hosting arbitration. Neutral ground. Binding agreement. That's the closest thing we get to justice out here.
[seriously] Even Kade agreed to show up. Not because she grew a conscience—because leverage works.
[determinedly] But we don't walk in with slogans. We walk in with facts. Economic data from six stations. Real costs. Real margins.
[quietly] My father died without ever seeing a table like this. I intend to sit at it like he deserves.
[directly] Gather the data. Bring it to Freeport. Let's write terms that actually keep people breathing.
[warmly] Thank you. This is the unglamorous part—spreadsheets and receipts. It's also the part that lasts.
[relieved] Data received. Kalla's already drafting the terms. For once, the math is on our side.
[emotional] I can almost hear my father's laugh. He'd hate the paperwork. He'd love what it means.
[determinedly] Union rights. Fair terms. A system that doesn't grind people down as a business model. We did it.
